question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the conventions of Roman drama, the various ways in which we can make deductions from historical evidence, and about the effects of Roman drama on later drama.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Reading ancient Roman scripts (tragedies, comedies, and historical drama). 
Identifying and analyzing different stock characters and their role in the plot and how they represented Roman values and perspectives. 
The interaction of politics and stage performances in ancient Rome.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: All things Roman drama. We talked about different types of plays, staging, scripts, tropes, Roman culture, politics, and more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about Roman tragedy, Roman comedy, and how to use different types of fragmentary evidence to make conclusions and learn about ancient Roman theater.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) Examining different kinds of evidence ranging from script fragments to artistic depictions of Roman drama 
2) Considering the roles of participants, patrons, audiences, and everyone in between in regards to the integral role of drama in Roman society
3) Discovering the tropes and stories of Roman comedy, tragedy, and historical drama, and considering their impact on modern storytelling.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We had reading assignments for each class, which worked well. The extra credit/make-up assignments were also excellent. The midterm and final project options were very interesting and fun.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the group workshops where we all would analyze different parts of a script and talk about our findings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Ginsberg is awesome. Such an inspiring person to learn from, even as someone not involved in classics. Reading long articles or full scripts can be tedious, but the discussion questions always keep you thinking and challenge you to analyze the text more deeply as you read. In-class discussions are always lively and filled with fascinating details. She asks questions that would never cross your mind but make you re-evaluate how you see the Romans. I think the layout of the course is really conducive to learning, discussion, and engagement.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked all of the plays that we read and the discussion board homework assignments on them. It was really cool to see my peers' thoughts on the readings and the discussion questions made me read more carefully. I also really liked having options for midterm and final assignments. While both options sounded interesting, I felt like I could choose the option that I felt the most confident on, which was super helpful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was INCREDIBLY thoughtful in its construction. Professor Ginsberg truly brought the ancient to life in the present by encouraging us to engage directly with evidence and notice patterns for ourselves. This easily could have been a boring, lecture-style class, but she invited us into the incredibly exciting world of being a Roman dramatist and made us all feel welcome in that space no matter our background. The combination of workshops, research, readings, discussions, lectures, and more created a learning environment that was vibrant and different every day.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was really neat to learn what historical evidence we have and how to interpret it!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I had no idea the role of politics in ancient roman drama and how it could be used as a vessel to safely criticize politicians.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: There are so many fascinating things about Rome and Roman theater that I would never have learned without taking this course. For the first time I am thinking about the Roman Empire, as the meme goes, several times a week. Reading the actual plays and learning about the real people behind it all really puts everything into a new perspective

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: All of the small group discussion in our in class workshops was stimulating because I got to hear ideas from classmates and bounce my own ones off of them.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Ginsberg's enthusiasm for the course content created an environment where everyone was encouraged to engage with the material in a really personal way. That created a collaborative, fun energy amongst the students - I felt like we all came to class every day excited to dig into new evidence.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Lauren Ginsberg is amazing and you should take the class. There are also many opportunities to make up work or get extra credit.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The scripts are so interesting! I never knew roman plays had so much drama. Plus, Professor Ginsberg IS SO PASSIONATE AND SO KNOWLEDGEABLE about this topic. It was genuinely fun to watch her lecture.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it!! Don't hesitate. I was unsure going into it. I am not a classics student, just someone with a vague interest from taking Latin. In all honesty I was just looking for a not-boring CZ credit. But this ended up being my favorite class this semester. It was interesting, engaging, a manageable work load, and I learned so much. It really rekindled my interest in Rome and was a fun refreshing part of my day.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT!!! You couldn't ask for a more exciting Area 2 Theater Studies class or CZ credit. If you think history is boring, just wait until Professor Ginsberg sweeps you up in the world of Roman drama, including everything from pranks to dragon chariots to the most insane things you could do to another person. It's awesome.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The way that our bodies move in space from everything as simple as how we walk are governed and influenced by different sociopolitical factors that typically we are unaware of. Dance can be used as a form of dialogue between our conscious and unconscious minds. The mind and the body are not distinct entities from each other, they are one and the same.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
I really appreciated how every person had to share a story each class, and had the freedom to share almost whatever they wanted, regardless of whether it was a story they had told before. It kept me thinking about storytelling but took away some of the pressure of having a new, life-changing tale each week. I also genuinely found the readings for this course engaging and helpful; I wish we had discussed them more during class times. 
I thought the start of the course was particularly engaging, when we were given storytelling prompts and told to generate ideas on the spot. I wish we had done more exercises like that related to idea generation throughout the course, as I really enjoyed it,

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the things I learned from this course was how to think outside the box. I was able to develop new skills of detail reading and thinking. Another thing I learned was annotating my thoughts with complete sentences. This allowed me to think freely, but also little by little it gave birth to awesome and newer ideas. Third thing I learned was how to write an "essay". I loved how much freedom we had to write our essays and I enjoyed the process of focusing on something we found really interesting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much! Coming into the course, I was really nervous because I didn't have much experience reading Shakespeare. It was great to be surrounded by actors in the class who could help me better read and decipher the plays as we covered them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a sense of the theatrical... an better understanding of how the written word can be played with in many ways, and nuance can be created through acting decisions... This changed the way I think about performance in dialogue and conversation in general

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Beckwith is a wonderful professor— so kind, caring, knowledgeable, and genuinely interested in what her students think. I also liked that our first written assignment was a more informal, explorative essay and the second one was a formal research paper— this helped me develop different skills and appreciate different forms of academic writing.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great way to get introduce to Shakespeare. For example, I have never read Shakespeare before and was always scared it will be hard. However, with this course, the professor was always explaining the plot and leading us to thinking different meanings within nature. I love how we got through a lot of stories in just one semester. I really fell in love with his writing, Shakespeare takes you to this whole new world. I am very grateful for this class and the professor because I got so much from it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great course to better understand Shakespeare!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Enjoy! Have fun reading and watching plays

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Beckwith is extremely enthusiastic about Shakespeare, and her passion is passed on to the students in her class! We are encouraged to voice our own opinions, whether or not they contradict hers. She has a great respect for each student's perspective.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dive in as much as you can

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class (or if not this one, something else with Dr. Beckwith)!! It’s one of my favorite classes I’ve taken at Duke. To be fair, I already knew I loved Shakespeare before I took the class, but it seems like even students who weren’t as experienced with Shakespeare enjoyed the class. You will have to do a lot of reading— it helps if you watch the plays instead of just reading them (take advantage of Duke Libraries’ access to wonderful productions by companies like the RSC, Stratford Festival of Canada, and Globe Theater), but also have a copy with good notes in the margins (like the Folger or Arden edition). There are only two major written assignments, which means that each one counts a lot in your grade, but I didn’t mind because it meant that for most of the course we could focus on reading the plays and discussing them in class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Knowledge of the American drama canon, how to analyze non-textual components of a play (set design, costume, etc), how to think about a play without seeing it performed

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read and analyze play effectively, including stage directions which I had never really been exposed to before. I learned how to properly participate in literature based discussion. I also learned how to write a paper comparing adaptations of a literary work across different mediums.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Learning how to read contemporary plays
- Best ways to analyze themes and motifs
- How to facilitate good discussion for various forms of media

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I became a more creative and observant thinker and writer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to read and analyze a play, especially in comparison to other types of literature. How to compare plays and how to discuss them in greater context of their time

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the method of comparing adaptations to original productions. I learned how to engage with material I found uncomfortable, and I learned how to evaluate productions from an unbiased standpoint.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to read a play, how to analyze the choices of playwrights vs directors vs actors etc., how to approach reading a play from different directions

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to more broadly read and discuss literature at a college level, how to analyze stage directions and non-dialogue elements of a play, how to use knowledge of the playwright's history and life to make informed inferences on their work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my close reading skills, particularly as it uniquely relates to plays. This includes analyzing stage directions, different interpretations of the plays, and contrasting popular performances.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to examine stage directions and interpret their deeper meaning in relation to the themes and symbolism of a play.
I learned the importance of knowing context surrounding an author/playwrite because it significantly impacts how the play is received.
I learned how set design and lighting can enhance audience experience without it being completely consciously understood. Tone and mood are important.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to read a play; how to analyze components of theater (like set design, costume, lighting, etc.) and how they further a playwright or director's message; overview of some major genres

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The prospect of reading and analyzing plays was itself a new methodology for me, and one I'm please to say I have enjoyed. Reading plays is a unique skill and I think this course did a fantastic job providing some guidance on how to do that without ever coddling or resorting to a "how to read theater" style lecture. In terms of insights, I think the course provided an outlook on the breadth and depth of American literature genres, styles, and movements in the past century or so, and has generally made more more eager and open to further exploring the category.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Thinking about plays through a critical lens, essay writing, and critical reflections after reading.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Mike is a very energetic and encouraging instructor. He is very attentive to students' interests and ideas, and he makes a lot of space for students to talk through their ideas in class. I also appreciate the level of feedback he gave to students' written assignments, for both weekly discussion posts and longer essays.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the pace of the readings and discussions. There were different methods to participate which made it comfortable and conducive to my learning as someone who gets anxious about talking at loud in times, especially in a course out of my comfort zone and known strengths.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the discussions we had each class and how we were able to say our thoughts freely but also have some guiding questions to help prompt us.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: That was an awesome environment. It felt friendly, warm, and inviting. This all started with the tone the professor set. He truly had our best interests (our engagement with the material and success in the course) at heart.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Lead a very engaging class, ensured a classroom environment that everyone was comfortable in, feel good about contributing to discussion, highly involved in essay writing processes

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor facilitated this by being very engaging and insisting on a technology-free environment which helped to make everyone very engaged in the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the posts before class because they helped me come into class prepared with things to discuss. And though I did not utilize this much myself, having the option of alternate means of participation was very much appreciated as someone who feels they used to struggle to speak up a lot

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed that although we were often discussing works that grappled with serious and sensitive topics, Dr. D'Alessandro always kept the class good-natured and laughing. I think when a class tackles these plays, this is especially important for keeping students engaged and excited to participate.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciated that Professor D'Alessandro provided important context for the plays and their playwrights at the beginning of every class. It allowed us to place the plays in their history and themes and better understand the intentions of the authors. I also enjoyed the performance review. I was able to see my fellow students put on a production of a play that we read in the course which was super fun!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor D'Alessandro was exceptionally receptive to all idea regarding each play. Art is subjective, and he never made us feel like our opinion was wrong as long as we could back it up with evidence from the text. He was very open to admitting if one of our points had changed his mind or was a new way of interpreting the play.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved this class a lot. I'm sad it's ending. Professor D'Alessandro created a super warm, fun, and welcoming class environment that fostered a lot of lively discussion about the text and got everyone engaged regardless of their personal background (or lack thereof) with theater. He was always willing to chat about the text and clearly cared about us as students and people. I liked the pace of the class—I felt super accomplished that I read like 2 texts a week in the class. I like the response posts and the fact that they are on Monday was helpful because I could read and think over the weekend and felt like I could take risk because there was low-stakes grading. I really enjoy the lectures at the start of class, especially learning about a playwright's background and watching clips of the texts live. The conference structure before essays was helpful. My peer review drafts were always horrible but at least they forced me to get something on the page. I also really liked the variety of plays we read, especially the political plays at the end and how different they felt from more abstract expressionism stuff at the beginning. The bad choices assignment was also fun.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor D'Alessandro, Kate, and Julia all did an excellent job guiding class discussions, providing jumping off points and keeping the class moving through some very interpretable texts with a very opinionated seminar without ever stifling discussion. It felt easy to share in class, even if my thoughts were not fully formed, and the environment felt casual enough to make jokes and foster some camaraderie while still feeling very intellectual.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I obtained skills for analyzing Shakespeare, discussing Shakespeare, and viewing adaptations critically.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had a casual interest in Shakespeare prior to this course, but this course taught me to really dive deeply into his works in ways I have not before. I learned a lot about the historical context behind Shakespeare plays and how that context can be recontextualized through adaptation for a modern audience. I really enjoyed this class as a means of thinking more deeply about film as a medium and how it connects to more historical mediums like plays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Close and wide engagement with Shakespeare in text, across genre/culture in adaptation through various mediums, and written articulation of thoughts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned about film techniques (sound, camera angles, mise en scene, etc.) which I did not know much about before
2. I learned about the different definitions of what it means for a movie to be an "adaptation" of something and that adaptations are not merely derivative of the text
3. I learned how to closely analyze the language Shakespeare uses throughout his texts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze films which is something I've never done before, especially putting them in conversation with texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I never know what to write for this question because it is hard to come up with a new method or skill you learn in every class. I really enjoyed all of the plays though. I suppose something I learned was just how much Shakespeare recycled themes and character tropes. I think it was fun to be able to see traces of his different plays bleeding into each other a little.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We went deep into analyzing Shakespeare texts as well as adaptations. I had never engaged with films like we did in this class, using cinematic terminology to discuss and analyze them. I think overall this made me more observant and a better reader/thinker.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze Shakespeare, Shakespearian films, and how to discuss aspects of Shakespearian literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about film techniques and terminology as well as read some scholarship on films (e.g. Mulvey's 'male gaze' theory). I read and reflected on a diverse range of Shakespeare plays and how they can be adapted into different times and cultures.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the freedom we have in when to submit our written responses and what we could write about.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the use of "gobbets" as a means of prompting analysis. They're a relatively low-stakes way to engage with whatever we're reading or watching, and I really enjoyed getting the feedback on it. It always felt like our professor was really interested in whatever we wrote about and why it struck us in particular. I also really enjoyed the balance between watching clips to spark discussion and letting us guide discussion naturally through conversation with each other.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Derek does such an incredible job at facilitating open discussion - he takes everyone's points seriously and is clearly so informed/knowledgeable on these plays. Writing our gobbets (reading responses, 8 total at any point in the semester) allowed me to synthesize my thoughts across the plays and their adaptations, and they were really accessible ways with engaging closely with the week's topics. Derek really made this class so fun, and his selections of the readings/plays/films were fantastic.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Derek made the course extremely conversational, allowing me to develop different perspectives on each text we read and movie we saw. He encouraged people to disagree with him, which left lots of room for independent analytical thought. I would keep this teaching style for future classes. Additionally, watching a variety of different Shakespeare adaptations, some strict and some loose, facilitated my understanding of what it means for a film to be an adaptation. I would continue showing films from different time periods and cultures in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought Derek found a wonderful balance between lecture and seminar, which is something I've struggled with in classes before. He always asked questions to prompt discussion, but also started each class with a 5 ish minute lecture that help put the lesson into context. I absolutely loved this course and think Derek would make a wonderful professor.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Witten is super interested in what he is teaching which is probably the most effective way to engage your students. I loved discussions, and it was fun to watch clips from the films. I hesitate to say I would keep the same plays in future years, because as much as I enjoyed them all, I think it would be more fun for Professor Witten to get to keep teaching new plays.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

Because there isn't a ton of time to work on it in class, it's entirely up  to you to ensure you work on it in a timely manner while balancing your other coursework.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Since I am not too knowledgeable about history, I am glad to understand history better.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about the Wiener Moderne time in Austria and Germany and how the societal factors happening at that time influenced the art that was being created, specifically the operas and plays. We learned how to read plays and operas in German, and how to critically analyze them. We also played a lot of theater games to help with our comfort on the stage.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: we learned to analyze theater of the wiener Moderne. I also think that exploring older German  theater helped me to improve my grammar, particularly my understanding of formal addresses, with which I had long had some difficulty. I also learned a lot of History about Austria-hungary, and Germany in relation to theater.

Creative placemaking, the interplay of public/private/non-profit institutions, and this is the biggest thing: a greater appreciation of arts institutions & events around me. Before this class, I really didn't look to go to museums or art exhibits or dance performances. However, my positive experiences with these aforementioned things have motivated me to go to more events around campus and Durham. I think this is most notable with the performances in Page Auditorium. I will also say this course has helped me network/ reach out when working with my community partner. This was especially relevant when I wanted to include an extra component in the project and I had to gather the resources/data from different teams in the organization and outside.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about what exactly is arts policy, various cultural institutions and its issues, leadership and value in the arts, cultural equity (audience and access, heritage and repatriation), creative placemaking, and creative economies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to improve my presentational skills, how to take efficient notes, and how to analyze musicals from multiple different points of reference.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: All of the many steps that go in to making a musical - everything from creative development to the business/marketing

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We dove into 4 main areas of musicals --> script and score, staging and performance, design, and marketing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course really taught me the ins and outs of musicals. We learned everything from the script and score to set design to marketing. I also learned how to really analyze both the content and behind the scenes aspect of musicals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze musicals in terms of their script and score, performances, design, and marketing. Through this course, I became a more discerning viewer of musicals and gained an understanding of truly how much work it takes for a Broadway musical to not just succeed, but come to be in the first place.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a ton in this course about how musicals are put together in a variety of ways. I learned about positions I did not have much knowledge about such as music assistants and marketing directors, I gained insight into what conventions make a musical score effective, and I learned about how set and lighting designers collaborate to tell a visual story.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how musicals work don't work in relation to so many different factors like design, marketing, casting, script and score, production and more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the written/musical construction of a Broadway musical, including widening my knowledge of Broadway culture in general. I learned the how these aspects interacted with the behind-the-scenes employees (including directors, choreographers, set designers, etc.) and how these best come together to create a unified piece. I also grew to understand the factors, other than the show content, that dictate the success of the show, including marketing, publicity, etc. There was truly a wide breadth of things covered in this course, but that all brilliantly worked together to give a thorough understanding of the Broadway industry.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze musicals by different types of musical numbers; the importance of the entire team that works together to produce a show; the deeper meaning that can be found in a show through strong analysis; a career in theatre is achievable through many different outlets.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me about how to develop an actor's dramaturgical toolbox, taught me about how to elevate my use of voice and communication, introduced me to how to prepare for a monologue audition, and developed a core warmup technique that can be used for the body and voice in acting situations and beyond.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to better my speaking, especially when it comes to doing readings of works of others. I also learned how to better my intentionality with my voice, with regards to tuning into different characters and understanding the drive and force behind them. Lastly, I learned how to appreciate theatre for what it is, especially considering that it is a subject that I have never taken before. I especially love Jeff's essays that he assigned, as they provided me with valuable insights into how other acclaimed artists think.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to block and stage a scene, taking every member of the audience into consideration
2. Acting requires going beyond the immediate scene and internalizing the character's background, thinking through the wider story that has led them to this moment
3. How to formally audition for scene (what to wear, how to introduce self, how to enter and exit, how to open the monologue)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to warm up properly as an actor (breathing, vocals, physical)
2. How to give and receive feedback with peers (What-ifs vs observations)
3. Auditioning and all of the little things that go with that process (slates, clothing, etc)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the foundation of becoming an actor. I read many plays and essays about acting that helped me develop a better understanding of theater and what goes into a 'good' performance. I learned that every good actor focuses on the 'other' whether that be your scene partner, your head vs your heart, etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the ideas of the "other," "character/scene arc," and "moment-before" as it pertains to acting in any kind of scene. It is important to know your character very well but as important to know the other people in your scene if there are others.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I would definitely keep the first exercise of the before and after story, as I believe most students felt a lot more comfortable sharing and performing after such an intimate assignment.

• The level of freedom we had in choosing our own scenes

For future years, I'd keep all the exercises we do in class as well as that one time when we were picking our monologues and all the papers were on the ground for us to read and pick. It was just so fun.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how an actor warms up before a performance or an audition with a focus on Breathing, Relaxation, Resonance, Physical and Vocal Stretch, and Articulation. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course was so collaborative and really gave me the freedom to explore new avenues of expression. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

Jeff is super encouraging, and helps create an positive environment that allows people to try things (even if they're shy), and is genuinely invested in your growth as an actor.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Acting inherently makes you think about a lot of things -- given a piece of text, you have to make it come to life, and in order to do that, you have to think about what the script is trying to say, and who is saying it. You have to be able to know the character you're acting in and out, all the given circumstances, in order to be able to play the character. Acting is all about storytelling, and figuring out how to make a story captivating is intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Everyone put a lot of effort into their performances and I think that made me much more invested in seeing their and my own improvement because of it

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're considering taking it, just take it. Regardless of your skill in acting, you'll probably get something out of this class, and it has just been delightful being able to take this class. Jeff is amazing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to act with more method, memorizing 45 second monologues and got more insight into watching and reading plays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned all the components that go into actual acting. We used new methods and approaches to acting each and every class that made it fun.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Meditation was huge. As we "walked through space," I was able to release tension within my body before beginning the acting process.Another thing I learned was how to score and deliver a monologue. Johann shared with us a guide he wrote about scoring a text. It was well-written and helpful. Why? Methods such as separating beats made me conscious about what each "line of thought" meant and how I intended to deliver it. One of the most important things I learned from his guide was that it's very helpful--perhaps necessary--to analyze the character I'm depicting and conduct research to be as realistic as possible.Beyond individual work, I also learned how to do this in collaboration with a scene partner by doing the 10 minute play. Specifically, I learned how to build off of someone's energy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reflection, analysis of preformed work

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to express myself through bodily movements, how to read and score a theatrical text, and how to perform in front of an audience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the importance of bodily awareness. We established this through group breathing exercises, walks through space, and dynamic partner energy exchanges. I also learned vocal control through monologue rehearsal. Thirdly, I learned to tell stories through eye contact.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Communication skills
- Being involved in a character and understanding their motivations 
- Acting in scenes both individually and in groups

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to memorize quickly, how to be comfortable presenting in front of others, and how to engage audiences.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was very very engaging and passionate which made class fun and an escape from my hard classes. I would keep the 45 second monologues and partner work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: He made sure each class had some new components so it was never boring and we were always on our feet.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yohann formed a relationship with all of his students and tailored his teaching to each student while still teaching the class as a whole.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Johann did a great job of creating a comfortable environment for novice actors. Many of us were nervous about doing something that took us so far out of our comfort zones, but the environment was very non-judgemental. He always spoke with kindness and positive reinforcement. He showed incredible kindness to me which I always appreciated.I would definitely recommend that he keep the "walk through space." Why? It was a great way to set the tone for a class, create somewhat of a surreal atmosphere, and overall made me feel ready to act. 
I recommend that he keep the monologues. Why? having that individual attention on me was very uncomfortable at first, but I (and I think most of the class would agree) I became more confident and it was nice to see that development. I think you should also keep giving students the option to choose which monologue of the three we did to do. I thought giving us that choice was liberating and allowed us to target our strengths.I also recommend that he continue assigning live plays for students to watch. During those performances, I thought about practices that the actors or directors did and recognized how they connected to theories or experiences I learned about / had in our class. Seeing live plays added to the learning experience.I also recommend that he keep the self-selected play. Why? It was a great way for student to cultivate their theatre identities. By having the choice to choose any modern play, we chose the monologue that most clearly represented us.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yes, very engaging

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class rarely felt like an “acting” class, which I believe is a good thing. There was emphasis on emotional exploration and connections with others in the course, which eventually lent itself useful to acting. I like how this course was structured in this way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Johann created an incredible environment where we were fully present and vulnerable with one another.

- attending plays outside of the classroom opens up your understanding and perspective on what more advanced acting entails

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Getting to read your own play and going to physical plays. I would say I think 4 plays is a lot to go to, but 3 is perhaps a more manageable number.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Acting is so difficult. It requires the courage to let yourself go somewhere out of one's comfort zone in front of many watching eyes. That pressure definitely added a complex and stimulating layer to everything that we had already put into acting.Scoring a text was incredibly stimulating. Why? It was like creating a whole world, using the text as the foundation. As we used the text, context, research, etc. to create a compelling monologue, this practice reflected creativity, which is the highest point on Bloom's Taxonomy, a hierarchy reflecting how stimulating learning activities are.Overall, the emphasis Johann placed on make deliberate choices within our acting made the course stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I like the methods used to explore characters in theatrical works, such as the images and playlists assignments.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a bit more about Aristotelian theater. I learned how to apply those concepts to other texts. I also learned a bit about designing around those ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: group work, class participation and different types of essay writing

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically evaluate both written and performed plays, what to consider in the staging of plays, and also what makes effective theater.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- how to assess a script as an artifact and a blueprint

- how aristelian elements of theater have persisted and been challenged

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about theater, how to use plays as both artifacts and blueprints. I learned a bit about playwriting, acting, directing, and designing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course I learned skills that not only shaped the way I viewed learning material (reading plays and understanding scene work) but it also allowed for me to see how all parts of theater are connected. We learned the historical backgrounds of many pieces while also understanding the foundations of acting in practice (Aristotle) and what makes a piece objectively successful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. plays as blueprints and artifacts
2. the broad history of the development of Western theater--how we get from The Bacchae to Cloud 9
3. how to think about productions in terms of efficacy, how to direct a scene so that it is an effective adaptation of the text

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learned how to analyze the wide blueprint of theater throughout history. I learned how to look at theater from the perspective of the writer, the director, the designer, and the actor. I also learned how to apply these concepts in a final production project.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
Chauntee' does not give A- or B+, etc.. She does only A, B, C, and D, so if you get below a 93, that's where the B begins. Just be aware because there are only five assignments, each worth 20 points, so you can't get off more than seven points total or else you'll get a B. 
There is also a research project towards the beginning of the semester that takes a substantial amount of time. You may not be told that you have to memorize a song for the performance part of that project, but if you bring in sheet music and refer to it when you sing, you will get points off. Prepare your song as if it's an audition. In your music video project, don't deviate from your previously-submitted plan without talking to Chauntee' first, as you will get points off if your final product is different than your plan.
Chauntee' gives good feedback on singing and acting, so I enjoyed working with her overall.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me so many useful skills, whether I decide to be a production manager for theater or not. Through the books we read, like Dan Heath's Upstream and Fearless Negotiating by Michael C. Donaldson, I learned how to preemptively stop problems from occurring, as well as how to negotiate and the most effective way to do so. Through our assignments, I learned how to organize and put together a calendar with important dates and events, as well as how to make a budget for both mainstage and repertory theater shows, which is a very useful skill. Knowing how to work with money and budget everything accurately is a skill important to all aspects of life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: That the class is is a lot of outside work which may be cumbersome if you also have a class that eats up a lot of your time. Overall though, if you have any interest in theater or management the class is very interesting. If you have no background in theater the class does cover most of what you would need to know. The knowledge gained from the class can be applicable in areas outside of theater as well, so it is still worthwhile. The class is pretty chill and Thom is very approachable, plus you get to enjoy two comped shows, one at the DPAC with a Q&A session with the cast and crew after, and another with the Duke Theater Studies Show. Additionally, Thom lines up a good selection of guest speakers with quality inside knowledge and stories which were interesting every time. For those reasons I recommend the class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

We learned how to read plays and operas in German, and how to critically analyze them. We also played a lot of theater games to help with our comfort on the stage.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: we learned to analyze theater of the wiener Moderne. I also learned a lot of History about Austria-hungary, and Germany in relation to theater.

course: THEATRST-226S-01 : WORLD BUILDING FOR THE THEATER.THEATRST-226S-01.

course: THEATRST-226S-01 : WORLD BUILDING FOR THE THEATER.THEATRST-226S-01.

And we learnt practical skills and actually contribute to a show "The Liar" by working backstage. I work in wardrobe and interact with the casts closely, which is really interesting.

course: THEATRST-226S-01 : WORLD BUILDING FOR THE THEATER.THEATRST-226S-01.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course isn't what it is advertised as. It is mostly just doing run crew for the show, and you don't do much or learn anything in class. If you want to get course credit for doing run crew in a main stage show, you could take this course. Keep in mind that you don't get to choose what run crew role you want (you rank them, but likely to not get your first choice).

course: THEATRST-226S-01 : WORLD BUILDING FOR THE THEATER.THEATRST-226S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you need an ALP to take and there's nothing that catches your eye, take this class even if you're not particularly interested in theater. It is extremely light load and you get to learn stuff not because you have to, but because you'll end up wanting to. Bill is also a really great guy and if you're taking other demanding classes, you'll end up wanting to go to this class at the end of the day to something fun like make a little stuffed bird or cut some wood, etc. There will some time commitment at the end though when it comes to making the actual play. You will be part of stage crew but I think at the end the pro outweigh the cons.
