question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! A good class to add to overload with. Not much work but it is fun and energizing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it!! I learned so much about dramatic writing, Professor Bell is a great professor and a great person, and we as a class had so much fun and bonded so much. Another great thing about this class is that by the end you will have a large portfolio of short dramatic works that you can submit to journals, readings, and competitions - I was able to have one of my pieces performed at the Duke Players Playhouse Shorts event and it was an amazing experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class! Or any class with Professor Bell. Because sharing writing is so intimate, you will form great bonds and connections with your classmates and teacher, which is really special. You will gain more practical writing experience and have the opportunity to workshop your pieces with a decent amount of people! Great for anyone interested in writing in the future, or anyone who loves writing/telling stories just for fun :)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Engage in class and do your work and you should be fine.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you enjoy creative writing, take this class. If you enjoy theater and want to get more experience on the playwright side, take this class. If you have no experience in writing or theater and want a fun and rewarding creative outlet, take this class. Come to class ready to engage with your peers' scripts, but that may not even need to be said because everyone in the class was eager to read each others' scripts. The only possible reason I can fathom that someone wouldn't be satisfied with this class is if they didn't put in any effort; this was not the case of anyone I know who's taken it, but I suppose in the abstract it is theoretically possible. I would STILL encourage that person to take this class because even shy or "too-cool-for-the-arts" students will get a kick out of this class. It is genuinely the most fun class I've taken at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE THE CLASS! It's the best!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a ton of fun! Buy in with the acting and writing and you'll have a great time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! Hands down my favorite class at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Come and be creative

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It may seem intimidating at first but the class is loads of fun and helps you learn a lot about both theatre and yourself a writer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The best class I've taken at Duke - learned things that are hard to articulate into words, but it was a life-changing experience. The group-based discussion allowed learning to emerge naturally, rather than forcing specific learning guidelines for the course

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to think about dialogue in a way others outside of this course typically would not, in that dialogue is an aleatory, unprecedented, and irreproducible interaction between people. When engaging in dialogue, instead of trying to hold onto the past or focus on the unrealized future possibilities, I should live fully in the present moment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned to view conversation as an anabolic mechanism towards new thought. I previously thought that talking was simply an exchange; I now know this is false.
2) I learned how to be present. My mind is constantly in a different place than my physical body but speaking in the present and engaging in dialogue with such a fascinating group of students showed me what it meant to be "here and now."
3) I learned a lot about "local knowledge." I didn't really get what this meant at the beginning of the course. However, after discussing what we do in class to someone outside of class, I realized I knew nothing about my classmates except who they were to me within the class -- locally.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to conceptualize and further explore the relationship between what someone says aloud and what they mean. We learned vocabularies and theories and developed our own to understand the significance of pieces of a conversation to dialogues as a whole, and to group dynamics as a whole.We learned to structure our class through consensus and group decision-making, sharing our priorities with others and reaching a class environment most helpful to achieving our aims in the dialogue laboratory.We learned how to approach the world dialogically, respecting the dynamics created by the perspective of others and forces in the world beyond our control.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new ways to think about communication, new practices to develop better communication, and how to pursue new ways of group reflection.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learning the meaning of kairos, interpretations of authenticity, other methods and terms pertaining to dialogue. 
2. Seeking dialogue in a different sense, learning to enter someone else’s “universe” and how to create a multiverse with your peers.
3. Learning about one’s own goals and how to advocate for progression and learning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I developed my skills with dialogue and communicating with people in the moment.
- I learned how to complete lab reports and analyses on small social group. 
- How to improve impact while speaking

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: - present thinking, understanding how I was using language, and education outside of the banking model

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was essential in the development of my dialogue and analysis skills, which will have wide implications for the rest of my academic experience at Duke. Not only that, but it facilitated an environment that championed social bravery and growth over comfort. I would also add that this class was so radical in design that it forced me to reevaluate my understanding of education as a whole, applying critical theory to the institutions that we hold in such high regard.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My instructor created a detailed section covering each concept discussed in class. He organized the information clearly and concisely, providing access to all assigned readings, which facilitated our learning progress. This organized scheme enabled me to efficiently track my learning.He offered us the chance to create our own class structure. From the first day, he taught us how to develop our own teaching methods. Gradually, he relinquished his authority as a teacher, allowing us to become both students and teachers simultaneously. This experience taught me creativity and hopefulness.In this course, I learned to be socially aware and humane. David emphasized how dialogue is the cornerstone of human connection and growth. A key concept, the I-Thou method by Martin B., was central to the course. It involves understanding the navigation (words) between different universes (people's minds) and their collisions (dialogue). The course showed me that dialogue is about being sensitive to those around us, a process of discovering and creating with a person rather than labeling them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Local knowledge, love for David Landes, knowledge of dialogue theories

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course is an anti banking model of education where a lot of the learning comes from class conversation accompanied by readings and resources provided by the professor.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: David created an incredible learning environment that allowed me to grow through the experiences, thoughts, and ideas of others. Keep the format just the way it is!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The fact that there was no strict written exam or quizzes, nor list of things to memorize or lecture materials to study made the course a lot more liberating to experiment in ways that facilitated genuine learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor facilitated my learned by being very unconventional in his teaching style. This was a refreshing respite from the monotonous learn, study, test of a typical Duke course that made me genuinely excited to both show up for the class and do classwork outside of class. The anarchic structure of the class facilitated my learned because there was no preset content that restricted students from learning what they collectively felt was important. If an unforeseen topic arose, it was welcomed and explored rather than shut down due to divergence from a set plan. Overall, I would say I would keep the methods of instruction the same for future years. However, this is not possible because the structure lay within the body of students that comprises the class and the teacher that comes along with it. So, perhaps keeping the instructor is all that can be done to try and make a class as successful and engaging as The Dialogue Laboratory of Fall 2023.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class's structure was broad and wide open to student interpretation. Dr. Landes created an environment in which we found consensus about our goals in the laboratory together and pursued them as a group of individuals always trying to understand our own motivations and those of others. The course's lack of pre-imposed structure was filled by a group dynamic where we'd explore the parts of dialogue we found most fascinating, which were often influenced by readings we'd do before class.There was a predefined structure to the extent that we'd come to class and converse with each other, share our thoughts and try to understand each other better. Also, Dr. Landes would step into the conversation and try to steer it to match group consensus and address runaway analysis among the group, bringing us back to the emotional basis of the conversation.Overall, the structure was ideal for this kind of laboratory. We'd read the background knowledge required to understand our own goals and to create a mutual understanding about the role of our laboratory in achieving them, and we'd structure class itself around those goals dynamically. This allowed us to pursue the ideas we found most interesting to a much greater depth, and allowed us to pursue our experimental aims free of restrictive class structure.I would keep the entire class structure into the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course structure is built to support student interests and needs. I suggest keeping the power in the hands of the students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the instructor’s method of getting us introduced early on before letting us go on our own helped establish the tone of the course. I think giving the students their own autonomy is the best method moving forward.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course facilitated my learning by doing away with the banking model and focusing on understanding and shared knowledge. In the future, I would continue with the professors way of choosing weekly readings based off of what the students need.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: By not having a bunch of gimmicks and forcing us to create our knowledge

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There is very little I would change about this class for future semesters, there is a relevant degree of self-determination in the life of the course, and I have no doubt that with Landes framework future groups of students will be able to change and model the experience to one that they personally can glean the most value from.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Our assignments employed a unique and effective method for teaching dialogue. After each class, we were tasked with creating three distinct reports: a reading reflection, a field report, and a laboratory report. This trilogy was fascinating, as each component required a different set of skills. Reading reflections improved our ability to recall and apply the most personally significant concepts from the readings. Field reports challenged us to apply classroom concepts in our daily lives. The laboratory reports, being the most crucial, helped us understand our individual and collective roles in the specific context and timeframe of each class. Essentially, we discussed the unique or local knowledge we created in our dialogue class.From this class, I learned that the most lasting concepts for the future include: "Pedagogy of the Oppressed," which highlighted learning and teaching as transformational processes and critiqued the current educational system's dampening effect on our desire to transform the world; "Creating Safe Spaces and Brave Spaces," emphasizing the importance of fostering transformation and hope for a better world; "Thought Leaders in Dialogue Theory," demonstrating that the idea of transformational praxis is not only advocated by Davis but has been systematically studied; "Kairos," stressing the importance of speaking at the right moment; "Social Choreography," encouraging a unique perspective on social interactions through spatial organization and people's responses; and "Semantic and Poetic Meaning," contrasting how semantic meaning often falls short in expressing complex emotions like love, whereas poetic meaning can capture these nuances.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The learning environment was left up to the class, and the professor did not force us to do anything. It was an open floor. Anarchy was the word that was introduced to the class on the first day as an adjective for the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was extremely stimulating because it relies on the active participation of everyone in the class. It was like a flipped format, where it is taught by the students, which is eye-opening compared to the traditional professor-student format.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The students and professor made this class stimulating. Aside from readings, this class was entirely focused on the people in Social Sciences 109 from 3:05-5:35 every Tuesday. The in-class dialogue was always entertaining because students had the choice to stimulate themselves with whatever dialogue they saw fit for the moment (kairos). However, a lot of my intellectual stimulation actually came from the weekly assignments. It was in these assignments that I did the most self-discovering and produced mind-blowing realizations or connections from both inside and out of the classroom.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating because we brought forward curiosities we didn't even know we had, and worked them out with a group of people in the same space as us. We created a group mind that truly tried, and often succeeded wildly, at understanding the feelings underlying our curiosity and addressing those points we were most interested in seeing addressed.These curiosities varied throughout the year, but letting dialogue succeed in bringing them forward meant that they were addressed to almost just the right depth and were constantly the focus of the class. So, for example, this class was intellectually stimulating in that it tested how language choices effected the way others responded to language, and also in how other dialogic choices such as body language tone and positional landmarks created different effects on dialogue. Whatever the specific hypotheses of the class demanded, we explored with one another. We got to see the effect of our interests in action, answering them more holistically. Finally, we refined the skills of approaching others and creating a group mind in action, which is something that can only be learned from experience.Its a very abstract course in some ways, but when the laboratory starts cooking it becomes very real and very personal in a matter of minutes. I think seeing how our abstractions related to real emotions was the most stimulating part of the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating because the learning happened in new forms that were non traditional for the classroom.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think this class was highly stimulating because it, at its core, depends on student participation. As long as the class is actively involved, I don’t see any other methods that would change this.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was without a doubt the most stimulating course I have taken. I believe this is because of the experimental and student driven structure. Every student has their own goals and objectives which makes them more inclined to complete course work.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class makes a proposition to its students that they have lived their entire (measurably successful) lives inside a very rigid definition of education and information transfer; it invites students to recognize and step outside these boundaries to create knowledge together in a more participatory mode of engagement.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I believe that, as this class is part of the arts and performance field, it resembles playing in a theater. The most stimulating aspect for me was the ability to express identity using both an intellectual and humane component. In every session, we were evaluated on a participation basis, which kept our brains active, encouraging us to think critically, openly, and humanely. I am considering taking this class again and feel that every professor should experience it too, as it fosters a sense of connection and applies the concept of 'scinus'—a genius arising from collective thought processes. This class has the potential to transform our rigid and erratic perceptions of growth. It encourages us to think collectively and individually, challenging the notion that society must be entirely individualistic.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The dialogue among the class, and the freedom to mold the class how we wanted to.

response_text: Take this class!! It is unlike any other course at Duke, and you can't miss this opportunity!

response_text: Don't try to think about what you are going to learn or have learned. Go with the flow.

response_text: Take this class if you are interested in being academically courageous and going on a journey that requires you to be vulnerable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Highly recommended, you learn a lot about dialogue, social interaction, and yourself.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a class unlike any other; it is paramount that you understand and are enthused by that idea because your engagement in the course is the course! This is a great class to take if you want space in your schedule to explore philosophy, rhetoric, and understanding of group dynamics, but it requires you to give something of yourself to it as well.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be open-minded and mature. This class focuses on learning how to brainstorm and create collaboratively. It's pointless if you only focus inward. Engage with ideas and concepts, and train yourself to understand the perspectives of those around you while exploring new ways of interacting with them. Most importantly, set your own expectations for your role in the course. It's a journey of personal exploration, so don't merely mimic others' behaviors. Instead, understand why they act as they do and how this understanding can enhance your interactions with them. Develop your own style; there's no right or wrong. Identify your objectives and be true to yourself.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a very different type of class, and David is very flexible. If you want to take a course that is challenging, and encourages you to talk and build relationships with your classmates take the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The Dialogue Lab completely transformed how I understand human communication. First, I learned to truly listen - not just to words, but to the subtle layers of meaning, emotion, and intention that flow beneath them. Second, I discovered how a group of strangers sitting in a circle can create an entirely new "collective consciousness" through dialogue, where our shared understanding becomes deeper than any one person's individual thoughts. Finally, and most importantly, I learned that what seems like "just talking" is actually an incredibly complex dance of human connection, where every word, pause, and response shapes not only our conversation but who we become as people.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: HOLY. Look. You learn skills that can't be taught anywhere else at Duke. You get to truly see people, and be seen as a person. It's an entirely different WAY of learning, and it's so challenging but so fun and (imo) much much less stressful than how we've been doing it for all of our lives. You're pretty much guaranteed a good grade as long as you buy in. With that being said, while this class doesn't demand stress, it does demand investment. You have to be present and attentive and willing to be a bit uncomfortable. Try it out!! You will 100% see if you love it or hate it within the first 2 weeks.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: - I learned to see conversations as a way to build meaning collaboratively, not just exchange ideas. I'm an international student, and taking this course with Prof. Landes has given me the language and toolbox to approach everyday conversations as fun toys rather than something we just "do". Notably, I don't think the course gave me "new tools" or "tips and tricks" for having conversation, but rather gave me (1) a space and a community to experiment with and get honest voices and advice about my communication, and (2) a language to explicate what might feel "right" or "wrong" within a conversation and what each action might contribute to a conversation.- I started recognizing that every interaction is shaped by interpretive lenses, helping me better analyze the dynamics at play. This idea was also formed in his past class (WRIT 101) and it plays hand-in-hand perfectly with this class. Two extremely impactful ideas that I continuously repeat to my friends that I've learned throughout my time learning with him were that (1) there is no such thing as an "objective" or "true" lens, and (2) particularities--not generalities--foster the relatability within a narrative/story. Definitely use the language we built in this class over interpretive lenses in my everyday life.- I realized the value of embracing ambiguity and using it to explore deeper, more nuanced perspectives rather than seeking immediate clarity. A lot of the people that come in are CS/Engineering majors that are very used to the dry-cut communication of numbers and fact (self-included). This course (and Prof. Landes' approach) give us a culture shock that "useless" conversations are where true humanity shows up and how people connect.

response_text: The structure of the course was the course content in a sense, and Dr. Landes was very effective in implementing it in a way that facilitated learning. I'd keep everything that is currently installed into the course for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The circular seating arrangement and lab-style structure of this course was absolutely brilliant - it broke down traditional classroom hierarchies and created this incredible space where we could truly experiment with communication. Landes was more like a skilled facilitator than a traditional instructor, guiding our discussions with light touches while letting us discover profound insights on our own. The weekly "lab reports" were genius because they forced me to process and analyze what happened in our discussions, helping me see patterns and dynamics I would have totally missed otherwise. I especially loved how responsive the course was to our group's specific needs - when we'd hit communication roadblocks or discover interesting tangents, the professor would adapt assignments and readings to help us explore those areas deeper, making everything feel incredibly relevant and personally meaningful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I've taken WRIT 101 and WRIT267S with Prof. Landes back-to-back. I've had a lot of conversations him inside and outside of the class, and he has definitely earned my full respect over the year or so that I've met him. It's the type of respect that comes when you know someone is *extremely* convinced and in love with what they do and put in the time to understand it and study it well. Once you speak to him and understand the context of his experience in the past, who he taught, his hobbies, you gain more and more of an appreciation to his relationship with the subject. You start to feel like it is his literal baby or "magnum opus". Regardless, Prof. Landes leads the class with the mentality of trying to simply enhance your growth, not particularly direct it. He gives advice and treats people as individuals with separate interests and personalities, which makes the class have a very amplified personality. Some of the advice, experiences, and lessons he has shared with me have even contributed to my personal life in an extremely concrete way. Conversations with him are dense with lessons that are applicable to the class and beyond.As for specific components of the course that stood out to me, the focus away from the usual educational banking model and letting the class direct the conversations of the day is definitely the star of the show for me. Prof. Landes is insanely good at letting conversations happen and only talking when he has to or when it adds to the conversation. I felt a real connection with the class for sure. There is a reason why I felt so strongly about taking this class after WRIT 101--similar feelings were felt in that course.

response_text: Absolutely phenomenal class. The class feels so personalized. You learn things you did not know you needed to learn about yourself.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great course, although it may be difficult to comprehend, you don’t have to get everything, as long as you feel that you got something, then that’ll stick with you forever

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Trust the process. The class seems odd and confusing at first, but I have learned more in the last 15 weeks than I have in almost any other class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about different ways to prevent generalizations in dialogue, learned that it is fine to not always have a plan, and learned so much more about how to enter the I-you space.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to dialogue more effectively and also how to reflect on dialogue both in the moment and retroactively. I also learned how to put my thoughts into language and explain them more effectively.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a an effective ways to tackle problems for personal growth through the process of dialogue beyond the banking-model used in most other courses. I believe this class has given me tools to become a better learner.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I definitely learned how to reflect and retheorize on moments of group communication. I learned a lot of theory, philosophy, and concepts about language that I had never been able to put words to before. And I learned ways of thinking and observing others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think about things from other people's perspectives, talk to other people while staying present, and become a better listener.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The biggest thing I've learned in this class is how to have more effective conversations. What I mean by this is being able to ask deeper questions and engage with someone rather than just "monologuing back and forth." Language is complex and so is dialogue. Being able to dissect dialogue on a greater level is something that I think is extremely relevant to any career leaving Duke.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the participant observer method, the difference between i - it and i - thou conversation, and how to put the concept of kairos into practice for better dialogue. Overall taught me a whole new way to view dialogue and changed so much of my worldview.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked the fact that no class had a given structure, loved starting the class by just asking how everyone is feeling, I really enjoyed how in control we were of our own lab and how we could drive the class as much as we wanted to.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: He provided out of the class readings which he would go over at the start of class. This helped take the confusing texts and put them in context. Open lab discussion time was very effective in teaching through the failures of the class. Often, I learned through seeing what did not work and where our conversations were very surface level.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was very freely structured, Professor Landes made sure we were on the right track and guided us but left decisions in the students hands.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: When we had open time to talk to one another, that facilitated us taking the wheel. This model is the essence of the class and should obviously be kept.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: David did a great job facilitating our learning by asking us where our understanding level was as we were going and letting us be very involved in our learning. I also liked when we discussed topics and then read about them it helped me understand more what I was reading.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: They open lab time was the best part of this class. Having the freedom to explore dialogue in a experimental setting was something unlike any other class I've had. Please keep this.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: i would keep almost all of it the same, I think this course is really well planned and thought out, and you can tell that David puts so much work into creating a space that maximizes learning. I think there was a lot of struggle involved, even though I knew what I was getting myself into because I had already taken one of Davids classes, but it was so so educational and the process of being confused and lost was key to the process. I loved this class so much, it taught me more than any other class at duke and I have full trust in David to design any class. This man could offer a class on watching grass grow and I would change my schedule to take it, and I just know that I would learn so much from anything he teaches.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was stimulating when we were able to learn form each other. The lessons were important to give us language and context, but I think the parts I was most engaged was open lab time.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was very intellectually stimulating because we were so involved as students. I was never bored and always thinking.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The forced failure, the mix of open lab / dialogue and readings, the freedom to do what we wanted but the option for structure, and the content of the course all made it incredibly stimulating. this class made me think way more than any of my other classes ever have.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think you should definitely take it if you want a course that will change the way that you think about something we do on a daily basis- dialogue. You will leave the course having so many more friends as well as amazing tools that will enable you to have more meaningful dialogue with people for the rest of your life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Buy into the course and put effort into learning as it is the only way to truly get anything out of it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is unique and you get to learn a lot about yourself and others in the class. It allows you to step out of your comfort zone and reflect on your role in you community and at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it, it's fun--not a ton of work outside of class and you get to meet other students. It's also a weird experience that you're never going to get in your other classes so I highly recommend!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be open minded and don't be afraid to make mistakes.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely do it, this was my favorite class I've ever taken at duke and it fundamentally changed the way I think about dialogue. It's definitely a struggle, especially at the start, but you learn so so much and the hard work and mental gymnastics are absolutely worth it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze movies in terms of incidents and dramatic action, adapting source material to screen and the many ways that can be done, and how to more accurately describe scenes in terms of action and meaning and uncover what the deeper meaning/main purpose is instead of objectively what happened.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

An understanding of dramatic action

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: You learn an approach to screenwriting that emphasizes dramatic principles---understanding your main character's motivation, how to structure a plot around incidents, and three-act structure.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: There was a lot of space for conversation and critically thinking which was intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class presented some very particular expectations and focused on skills I haven't had to think about before. The process of figuring out the incident lists for a given movie and determining character motivations really made me think.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it! It was very helpful for both writers with experience and writers without experience and everything in-between.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is my favorite class I've taken at Duke

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

course: THEATRST-284S-01 : HOW TO WRITE A HORROR MOVIE.THEATRST-284S-01.CINE-281S-01.ENGLISH-223S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
This is such a unique course, and was a wonderful experience! I think the horror genre is fascinating, though I hadn't had much contact with it previously, and it's great that we got to engage with it in an academic context. Professor Bell was great, and I had so much fun with this class. There's a lot of writing, but I think that's a good part of the class. Making myself dive into writing for a new medium (as I had no previous experience with screenwriting) is what really started to give me a sense for what goes into a script.
Stay on top of your long script at the end, though. Checkpoints are built into the class, so don't get behind on them, because that 80 page script is very manageable if broken up over multiple weeks, but very scary if you've let it pile up!

course: THEATRST-284S-01 : HOW TO WRITE A HORROR MOVIE.THEATRST-284S-01.CINE-281S-01.ENGLISH-223S-01.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of skills that I haven't had the opportunity to develop at Duke as a stem student. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to format scripts, work with a writing team, analyze pilot episodes and engage with industry professionals involved in screen writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-generation of ideas beyond what tv shows already exist
-how to format a script/what tools are available at my disposal to creatively express what I want in a show
-the challenges of continuity when designing a season

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to create more natural dialogue, how to write more concisely, and how to work with others who might not have the same writing styles/ideas

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class we were thinking about how to plot, format, and write television screenplays. Specifically, we created a TV episode in a "season two" of an already-released television show, and we created the pilot episode of our won original TV show. Through this class I learned about screenplay formatting, the level of detail required to write a TV episode, and how to connect plot points in a sensical way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
I really appreciated how every person had to share a story each class, and had the freedom to share almost whatever they wanted, regardless of whether it was a story they had told before. It kept me thinking about storytelling but took away some of the pressure of having a new, life-changing tale each week. I also genuinely found the readings for this course engaging and helpful; I wish we had discussed them more during class times. 
I thought the start of the course was particularly engaging, when we were given storytelling prompts and told to generate ideas on the spot. I wish we had done more exercises like that related to idea generation throughout the course, as I really enjoyed it,

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I obtained skills for analyzing Shakespeare, discussing Shakespeare, and viewing adaptations critically.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had a casual interest in Shakespeare prior to this course, but this course taught me to really dive deeply into his works in ways I have not before. I learned a lot about the historical context behind Shakespeare plays and how that context can be recontextualized through adaptation for a modern audience. I really enjoyed this class as a means of thinking more deeply about film as a medium and how it connects to more historical mediums like plays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Close and wide engagement with Shakespeare in text, across genre/culture in adaptation through various mediums, and written articulation of thoughts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned about film techniques (sound, camera angles, mise en scene, etc.) which I did not know much about before
2. I learned about the different definitions of what it means for a movie to be an "adaptation" of something and that adaptations are not merely derivative of the text
3. I learned how to closely analyze the language Shakespeare uses throughout his texts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze films which is something I've never done before, especially putting them in conversation with texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I never know what to write for this question because it is hard to come up with a new method or skill you learn in every class. I really enjoyed all of the plays though. I suppose something I learned was just how much Shakespeare recycled themes and character tropes. I think it was fun to be able to see traces of his different plays bleeding into each other a little.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We went deep into analyzing Shakespeare texts as well as adaptations. I had never engaged with films like we did in this class, using cinematic terminology to discuss and analyze them. I think overall this made me more observant and a better reader/thinker.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze Shakespeare, Shakespearian films, and how to discuss aspects of Shakespearian literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about film techniques and terminology as well as read some scholarship on films (e.g. Mulvey's 'male gaze' theory). I read and reflected on a diverse range of Shakespeare plays and how they can be adapted into different times and cultures.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the freedom we have in when to submit our written responses and what we could write about.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the use of "gobbets" as a means of prompting analysis. They're a relatively low-stakes way to engage with whatever we're reading or watching, and I really enjoyed getting the feedback on it. It always felt like our professor was really interested in whatever we wrote about and why it struck us in particular. I also really enjoyed the balance between watching clips to spark discussion and letting us guide discussion naturally through conversation with each other.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Derek does such an incredible job at facilitating open discussion - he takes everyone's points seriously and is clearly so informed/knowledgeable on these plays. Writing our gobbets (reading responses, 8 total at any point in the semester) allowed me to synthesize my thoughts across the plays and their adaptations, and they were really accessible ways with engaging closely with the week's topics. Derek really made this class so fun, and his selections of the readings/plays/films were fantastic.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Derek made the course extremely conversational, allowing me to develop different perspectives on each text we read and movie we saw. He encouraged people to disagree with him, which left lots of room for independent analytical thought. I would keep this teaching style for future classes. Additionally, watching a variety of different Shakespeare adaptations, some strict and some loose, facilitated my understanding of what it means for a film to be an adaptation. I would continue showing films from different time periods and cultures in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought Derek found a wonderful balance between lecture and seminar, which is something I've struggled with in classes before. He always asked questions to prompt discussion, but also started each class with a 5 ish minute lecture that help put the lesson into context. I absolutely loved this course and think Derek would make a wonderful professor.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Witten is super interested in what he is teaching which is probably the most effective way to engage your students. I loved discussions, and it was fun to watch clips from the films. I hesitate to say I would keep the same plays in future years, because as much as I enjoyed them all, I think it would be more fun for Professor Witten to get to keep teaching new plays.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like how Professor Witten kept the class very interactive and promoted collaboration among students. He was extremely energetic and excited about the material he was teaching, which made me look forward to this class every day!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that even though it was on the bigger end of a seminar we were able to still have the 'seminar' component through the use small groups and the teacher's ability to lead and engage the class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think I mostly enjoyed the balance between professorial commentary and student talking, but sometimes I wish that we as students guided the discussion a little more. Sometimes it felt like our professor sort of wanted us to hit a certain point of view or answer, and I was uncertain of what we might be supposed to be getting at which made me hesitant to talk. I almost wish we got to start with some sort of gauge of how everyone felt about the play/film, and find points of discussion from there.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the balance of text and film was very good, and the separation of units made it so that a good mix of plays were covered. I liked that the course engaged with non-American content.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Modern/contemporary application of Shakespeare as discussed through adaptation made it so clear how continuously relevant Shakespeare's stories are to us today, and have been across time. We were encouraged to form connections across the plays, bring in historical context, and reference Shakespeare's own personal history to inform our readings.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was made stimulating because it allowed me to examine Shakespeare through a variety of lenses, gaining an understanding of both the potential and limitations of Shakespeare's original source material. Additionally, the class's discussion-based nature made it stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: While the course takes a lot of time outside of class, the content is very engaging and allows you to explore the subject in a way that is most interesting for you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I really enjoyed this class, but it is key to make sure you manage your time well! Even though reading plays and watching films is mostly enjoyable, it is still time consuming and it might feel easy to let things fall by the wayside. It is also important to really think about your final paper throughout the semester. Because there isn't a ton of time to work on it in class, it's entirely up  to you to ensure you work on it in a timely manner while balancing your other coursework.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course! Derek is incredible at making Shakespeare accessible on every level, and you'll almost certainly fall in love with these plays if you weren't already convinced of Shakespeare's storytelling abilities. Discussions were always so much fun, even just listening - the work for this class was genuinely my favorite to complete out of all of my classes. The film selections are fantastic as well as we discuss across genre and culture. There's no reason not to take this course, especially if you're an English major!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class, whether or not you love Shakespeare. Derek's insight, as well as that of your classmates, will open your mind to interesting ways of interpreting Shakespeare's material.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Devon is a great professor, and must keep teaching! He is so passionate about the material and bring the energy to each and every class period. His passion, energy, vibrance, knowledge, and enthusiasm alone puts him in the upper tier of teachers I've had at Duke.However, I will say that his lack of experience teaching does show sometimes, as he occasionally will go on long, hardly-related tangents and/or talk over the class and speak for the vast majority even when its supposed to be discussion. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to understand Shakespearian texts and analyze what my character is saying. I learned how to identify her motivations and turn those into actions on stage. I learned how to be more commanding on stage and access a wider swing of emotions within a scene.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the language and structure of Shakespeare plays, acting techniques useful for both Shakespeare plays and acting in general, and the creative process that goes into creating a show.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned lots of interesting techniques and strategies for acting (such as finding "action words" to express the motive/purpose of each line, or imagining the size of your character's "bubble"), developed my comedy skills, and even received some stage combat training!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Jonathan was involved with all aspects of the process and helped immensely with all new aspects

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Jonathan did a great job of ensuring we understood what we were saying before attempting to act out the scenes. He also did a great job of letting us give ideas for blocking and ways that we could interpret scenes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The structure of this course was great. First, we started out by learning about the music, set, and costume design, which established the atmosphere for the play and its world. Then, because Shakespeare plays contain a lot language we don't typically use today, we did a lot of tablework to ensure we knew what we were saying when we were on stage. Finally, we went through our scenes in a rehearsal room before moving to the performance space a few weeks before the show started. I think the tablework was very important, especially for a Shakespeare piece, and Jonathan made the long sessions interesting by throwing in interesting bits of trivia. In general, Jonathan was a great director and instructor. He was very welcoming, kind, and understanding. He made a genuine effort to get to know everyone as an individual from the very beginning. He was very receptive to our feedback, and it felt like we were all able to contribute to the creative process because of this. Jonathan is incredibly knowledgeable about Shakespeare and his work, so he provided a lot of valuable insight into what Shakespeare was trying to do in a specific scene or phrase, which helped inform our acting. I felt like I was able to learn a lot because of Jonathan's engaging and informative instruction.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Jonathan was a terrific director– creative, kind, funny, and inspiring. The rehearsal schedule was intensive enough that I felt prepared for the show but not so intense that I felt overwhelmed by the time commitment. I'm so glad I participated in this production!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Engaging with Shakespeare deeper than I ever had before I had an immaculate opportunity to better myself

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think diving into the material made me really think about what my character was saying and what she was trying to get in the scene. That kept me engaged with the scenes I was in. I also liked learning about the background of Shakespeare and the place the show was set in.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I appreciated that we really investigated the text thoroughly in our tablework. It was important to understand the language not only so you could understand what's happening in a scene and what you're saying, but to better understand the world of these characters. Through the bits of trivia Jonathan threw in, I felt like I was able to better understand their world and why they said the things they said and acted the way they acted. This tablework was intellectually stimulating and crucial to delivering a good performance. Furthermore, it was intellectually stimulating to learn new acting techniques through watching Jonathan and the rest of the cast. Because Jonathan has so much experience, it was really fascinating to observe how he chose to deliver lines or direct a scene, and I learned a lot from this. Since the rest of the cast was so talented, I also learned a lot from being present in rehearsals and getting to watch them. Overall, this class was intellectually stimulating both on- and offstage!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The acting exercises, interactive structure of rehearsals, encouragement to keep a production journal to explore our characters and document our journey, and, of course, the magical process of getting the show together were all stimulating!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Welcome to the Mainstage and great job

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The mainstage show is definitely a large time commitment, so make sure you have enough time for it, especially during late October and November. But it's such a fun experience because you learn a lot about acting and get to bond with a great cast. Take risks! Make big choices in rehearsal so you can ensure you're getting the most out of the character in the actual performances. And believe in yourself. You were cast for a reason.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It was really enjoyable to be in a mainstage production. The production quality is insane and everything is so professional - it's definitely a different experience than what you may be used to. This was a great opportunity to work with a talented cast and creative team and really grow my acting abilities. Although Jonathan was absolutely spectacular, I'm sure the other professors at Duke who direct shows would also provide a great experience for students. I would definitely recommend taking this course!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
